Crypto ถึงเวลาตัดสินใจ: ความเหนื่อยล้าจากฤดูหนาวเจอกับความเสี่ยงที่ราคาจะลงลึกกว่าเดิม

Crypto at a Crossroads: Winter Fatigue Meets the Risk of Lower Lows

3d ago//Editorial
general
AI

Summary

TH

ตลาดคริปโตกำลังอยู่ในฤดูหนาวทางจิตใจ โดยมีความคิดเห็นที่แตกต่างกันเกี่ยวกับควางใกล้จุดล่าสุดของตลาด ตั้งแต่เดือนมกราคม 2025 บิทคอยน์ลดลง 39% จากจุดสูงสุดในเดือนตุลาคม เอเธอเรียมลดลงเกิน 50% และ altcoins ขนาดใหญ่ลดลง 60-75% แม้ว่า Matt Hougan หัวหน้า CIO ของ Bitwise จะเชื่อว่าตลาดใกล้จุดสิ้นสุดของฤดูหนาวมากกว่าจะเริ่มต้น โดยกล่าวว่า 'ฤดูหนาวของคริปโตไม่จบลงด้วยความตื่นเต้น แต่จบลงด้วยการเหนื่อยล้า' Alex Thorn จาก Galaxy Digital เตือนถึงความเสี่ยงที่จะลดลงต่อไป อาจถึงราคา 60,000 ดอลลาร์ ซึ่งเป็นการลดลง 50%+ ตามประวัติศาสตร์ แม้จะมีสัญญาณของเสถียรภาพ โดยการขายของเจ้าของระยะยาวชะลอตัวลงและ fundamentals ดีขึ้นตาม Cosmo Jiang จาก Pantera Capital แต่ราคายังคงค้นหาจุดลงทุนระดับ capulation

EN

The cryptocurrency market is in a psychological winter with mixed opinions on its proximity to a bottom. Since January 2025, Bitcoin has fallen 39% from its October high, Ethereum over 50%, and large-cap altcoins 60-75%. While Bitwise CIO Matt Hougan believes the market is closer to winter's end than beginning, noting that 'Crypto winters don't end in excitement; they end in exhaustion,' Galaxy Digital's Alex Thorn warns of further downside, possibly to the $60k range, as historically 40% drawdowns have become 50%+ declines. Despite these concerns, there are signs of stabilization, with long-term holder selling slowing and fundamentals improving according to Pantera Capital's Cosmo Jiang, though prices continue searching for a capitulation-level bottom.

Key Points

  • Crypto market is in psychological winter with Bitcoin down 39%, ETH down 50%+ since Jan 2025
  • Bitwise CIO believes closer to end of winter than beginning; Galaxy Digital warns of further downside to $60k
  • Long-term holder selling has slowed, fundamentals improving, but prices still searching for capitulation bottom

Article

Market veterans say crypto is deep in a psychological winter, with stronger fundamentals clashing against the growing risk that prices still need one more washout. Posted February 3, 2026 at 9:13 am EST. A growing number of market watchers agree on one point: crypto is deep in a winter. Where views diverge is how close the market is to a durable bottom , and how much more pain may come first. In a note sent to clients on Monday, Bitwise CIO Matt Hougan argued that the industry has effectively been in a bear market since January 2025 , even if ETF flows masked the damage for much of last year. Bitcoin is down roughly 39% from its October 2025 high , Ethereum more than 50% , and large-cap altcoins without institutional support have fallen 60%–75% . This story is an excerpt from the Unchained Daily newsletter . Subscribe here to get these updates in your email for free Hougan’s conclusion was psychological as much as analytical: “Crypto winters don’t end in excitement; they end in exhaustion. ” By historical standards, he believes the market is closer to the end than the beginning. That long-term framing contrasts with a more tactical warning from Galaxy Digital’s head of research Alex Thorn. In a Feb. 1 note , Thorn wrote that bitcoin’s structure points to further downside , citing weak price action, macro uncertainty, and one of the largest liquidation cascades in history. Bitcoin fell 15% in four days , briefly trading near $75,600 , below both ETF average cost basis ($84k) and Strategy’s average purchase price ($76k). Nearly 46% of BTC supply is now underwater , a level historically seen near major bottoms, but not always the final one. Thorn highlighted that outside of 2017, every 40% drawdown from an all-time high eventually became a 50%+ decline , which would imply prices closer to the $60k range , near realized price ($56k) and the 200-week moving average ($58k). Still, there are signs of stabilization beneath the surface. Long-term holder selling, which averaged $500 million per day in 2025 , has notably slowed. On Monday’s Bits + Bips livestream , Cosmo Jiang from Pantera Capital said “fundamentals are a lot better and trending in the right direction,” while Austin Campbell added, “I don’t think there’s been a better time for the industry and the forward path of adoption.” The picture that emerges is nuanced: structurally healthier crypto markets, improving fundamentals, but a price still searching for capitulation-level conviction . Whether exhaustion has arrived — or still lies ahead — remains the open question.
